sections.title: We dissect 67 Singapore Budget Statements delivered over the past 61 years to find out how the social compact has shifted.
sections.setup:
A Budget speech isn't just an accounting exercise.

It's one of the few moments each year when the government explains how the country is supposed to work.

sections.title: We dissect 67 Singapore Budget Statements delivered over the past 61 years to find out how the social compact has shifted.
sections.setup:
Behind each policy detail is an expectation of who must tighten belts, who must innovate, and who will be cushioned. Stack all the speeches together, and a pattern emerges from the language.

As the words change, so does the social contract.

sections.title: We dissect 67 Singapore Budget Statements delivered over the past 61 years to find out how the social compact has shifted.
sections.setup:
Each box represents one paragraph from a Budget speech in which the Finance Minister described what the government will do â€“ and what is expected in return.

For the purpose of this project, "social compact" is defined in a specific, limited way: it is the distribution of promises and demands the state assigns to citizens and firms in the language of Budget speeches.

sections.title: The trend across four Prime Ministers
sections.setup: The ratio of promises to demands has grown with each tenure.
sections.reflection:
Under Lee Kuan Yew, promises barely outweighed demands.
By Lawrence Wongâ€™s era, there were nearly three promises for every demand.

sections.setup: Earlier Budgets leaned heavily on demands: telling citizens to work harder, tighten their belts and stay competitive rather than expecting help.

sections.title: "The world owes us nothing"
sections.setup: Singapore had just separated from Malaysia. There was no safety net. The message was clear:
sections.quote: This confidence must not lead our people, whether entrepreneurs, or trade unionists, into believing that the world owes us a living and that things will always be all right. They will be all right only if we are constantly alert, efficient and striving.
sections.speaker: Lim Kim San
sections.reflection: Security was conditional, and the burden was yours.

sections.title: "Kill the goose before the golden eggs are laid"
sections.setup: Workers who asked for better pay were warned:
sections.quote: Our workers must also be prepared for factory discipline and hard work to make costs competitive. There must be restraint and discipline... Let our industrialisation be established first before we think of sharing the gains. Anti-nationalist elements are trying to dupe workers into prematurely demanding benefits which will kill the goose even before the golden eggs are laid.
sections.speaker: Lim Kim San
sections.reflection: Asking for help was almost unpatriotic.

sections.title: "An inhospitable swamp"
sections.setup: The government invoked Singapore's forefathers:
sections.quote: What is now needed is a return to the pioneering spirit of our forefathers who by their dynamism, hard work, and self-sacrifice turned what was an inhospitable swamp into the largest port in South-East Asia.
sections.speaker: Lim Kim San
sections.reflection: If the forefathers endured, so should you.

sections.title: "Nothing is for free"
sections.setup: As Singapore got richer, the government worried citizens were getting soft:
sections.quote: Our survival depends, as then, upon a robust approach to life, that the world does not owe us a living. Nothing is for free. Hence, the virtues of thrift and hard work... The question is whether we have not already been softened by the increasing affluence.
sections.speaker: Hon Sui Sen
sections.reflection: Affluence was treated as a risk.

sections.title: "To achieve nirvana, you must first experience pain"
sections.setup: A painless Budget still came with a lecture:
sections.quote: It is a completely painless budget, and even mildly pleasurable. But there is a moral to this, and that is, to achieve nirvana you must first experience pain. We have all worked hard in the past. We have all made sacrifices. We have never flinched from the harsh realities of the world.
sections.speaker: Goh Chok Tong
sections.reflection: Even comfort required justification.

sections.title: The turning point
sections.setup: Then came the Asian Financial Crisis. The government more readily acknowledged that people needed help:
sections.quote: Government is mindful of the difficulties faced by individuals and households in the current economic downturn. The cost-cutting package announced in November 1998 was focused mainly on reducing business costs. I will therefore be announcing several measures to help individuals.
sections.speaker: Richard Hu
sections.reflection: "Help" entered the vocabulary.

sections.title: "A key feature"
sections.setup: Help became systematic. Programmes got names. The generation once told to sacrifice was now being honoured:
sections.quote: A key feature in this year's Budget is the Pioneer Generation Package. As the Prime Minister has stated, we are honouring this unique generation of Singaporeans who built up the country.
sections.speaker: Tharman Shanmugaratnam
sections.reflection: The state moved from exhorting sacrifice to honouring it.

sections.title: "We will leave no one behind"
sections.setup: Covid changed everything. The government made a promise that would have been unthinkable in 1965:
sections.quote: We will protect and advance the well-being and livelihoods of Singaporeans. We will take care of our people. We will leave no one behind. And we will stand with Singaporeans from all walks of life to battle this crisis together.
sections.speaker: Heng Swee Keat
sections.reflection: The state wasnâ€™t just managing the crisis. It was shielding people from it.

sections.title: "We will protect every worker"
sections.setup: The government went further:
sections.quote: While we will try to preserve jobs in the midst of this crisis, we cannot protect every job. However, you have my assurance that the Government will protect every worker.
sections.speaker: Heng Swee Keat
sections.reflection: Jobs could go. Protection would not.

sections.title: The new normal
sections.setup: Was this just crisis language â€“ or the new baseline?

sections.title: "Always have each other's back"
sections.quote: We want every Singaporean to know and feel that he or she has a stake in our society â€” that everyone's contributions matter and that they will not be left to fend for themselves when times are down. We want to uphold that sense of obligation to each other and strengthen the assurance that, whatever the challenges we face, we will always have each other's back.
sections.speaker: Lawrence Wong

sections.title: "Strengthen our social compact"
sections.quote: We will strengthen our social compact and provide better support for families, seniors and vulnerable groups.
sections.speaker: Lawrence Wong

sections.title: "We will always have your backs"
sections.quote: Let me assure everyone â€” we will always have your backs.
sections.speaker: Lawrence Wong

sections.title: "We have each other's backs"
sections.quote: We want to build a Singapore where we have each other's backs, where no one is left behind and where we continue to stay strong and united as one people.
sections.speaker: Lawrence Wong

sections.title: "Together we will secure a brighter future for all"
sections.setup: The most recent Budget speech:
sections.quote: This is the conviction that underpins Budget 2026. It is a Budget to support Singaporeans today, prepare our society for tomorrow, and enable us to navigate this changed world with confidence. Together we will secure a stronger, fairer, and brighter future for all.
sections.speaker: Lawrence Wong
sections.reflection: Five years on, the language of support has settled in.

sections.title: A gradual shift, then a pivot
sections.setup: The 1960s started with more demands than promises. By the 2000s, the ratio had flipped.
sections.reflection: Notice the dip in the 2010s and 2020s? That's when demand language returned â€” but with a different tone.

sections.title: "Empower each Singaporean to chart their own journey"
sections.setup: In 2015, the government launched SkillsFuture â€” and with it, a new kind of demand:
sections.quote: We will build on these foundations to create a new environment for lifelong learning. It is critical to our future. It will develop the skills and mastery needed to take our economy to the next level. More fundamentally, it aims to empower each Singaporean to chart their own journey in life and gain fulfilment at work, even in their senior years.
sections.speaker: Tharman Shanmugaratnam
sections.reflection: In 1965, the call was to work harder for the nation. By 2015, it was to upgrade yourself for it.

sections.title: "Make the most of the support"
sections.quote: I encourage employers and workers to make the most of the support that the Government is offering. Upgrade your businesses; invest in innovation and training; reskill and upskill to stay competitive and seize new opportunities.
sections.speaker: Lawrence Wong
sections.reflection: The message? Weâ€™ll support you â€“ now move.

sections.title: The language tells its own story
sections.setup: Across 61 years and nearly 700,000 words, certain terms rose while others faded.

sections.title: Words that were once rare
sections.setup: Each sparkline shows how often a word appears, measured as mentions per 10,000 words, from 1965 to 2026.
sections.reflection: Support. Help. Families. Seniors. The language shifted to name who the government serves.

sections.title: "Support" â€“ from rare to everywhere
sections.setup: Between 1965 and 1975, the word appeared twice per 10,000 words.
sections.reflection: By 2017-2026, it appeared 60 times per 10,000 words. The government now uses the language of support 32 times more often than it did at independence.

sections.title: Words that have faded over time
sections.setup: These words were central to early speeches. Now they occur infrequently.
sections.reflection: Trade. Export. Manufacturing. Construction. The language of nation-building faded.

sections.title: Vocabulary of each era
sections.setup: Each Finance Minister left a linguistic signature â€“ words they used far more than others.
sections.reflection: First battalions. Now vouchers.

sections.title: The expectation persisted
sections.setup: These words appeared consistently across all six decades:
sections.reflection: The language of self-improvement runs through every decade.

sections.setup:
The government never really stopped asking things of society. It just stopped sounding so stern about it. There's support. There's reassurance. There are promises to cushion, to protect, to have your back.

But beneath that reassurance, the old rhythm remains. Keep up. Upgrade. Stay useful. Do your part.

The world may no longer be said to owe us nothing. But we are still expected to earn our place in it.
